SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you have stories to tell, all there is not sufficient space, give them in detail, or describe particularly interesting things that may help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1874, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
McGrae, Thomas
1006 - 1st Ave. N.E., Moose Jaw.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Working on a dairy farm & working some of the time on the land. Working on a ranch for a while same place. Lake Johnston starting something in the Moose Jaw area.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not too often. Probably monthly.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married in 1901 in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

Not too sure.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Only on visits.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Many experiences in early settlement days.

But none of special note.

"Or you," she wrote, "were we pleased in the west."

"We were pleased with our new home. C.C.M."

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? New fare? By what means of travel?

Considerable visiting was done among ranchers.

Not often & done by horse & buggy or sometimes by train back. A Sunday church service was held at times several homes during summer months.

Distance was generally between 4 & 20 miles.

"We were free."

A branch line of the B.P.R. was built in 1913 and trading was mostly done at Estevan, Sask., afterwards.

Very seldom. Probably monthly or quarterly.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

This habit has not arrived yet. Is any?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.

Certain articles of clothing & incidentals were purchased from mail order stores since 1901; but seldom in later years. Probably 1/4 of purchases in any year.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Had no definite plans; but decided to remain after a few months; May 1899.

Not to my knowledge

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Quite a few left; but few returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I held the office of Reeve of R.M. of Hillborough No. 132 for some years. The dates are uncertain; but retired in 1947.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The most important change has been the change from a purely ranching country to mixed farming district with all government lands under grazing lease & fenced & of course the building of roads since the formation of the R.M., also telephone service & railway service.
